subject: Lexical sets and QS letters
msgSnippet: Here s a rough mapping from the 27 Wells lexical sets (reminder: you can see sample words at http://www.ic.arizona.edu/~anth383/lexicalsets.html ) to QS vowel
messageBody:
Here's a rough mapping from the 27 Wells lexical sets
(reminder: you can see sample words at
http://www.ic.arizona.edu/~anth383/lexicalsets.html )
to QS vowel letters and combinations:

KIT #26 It
DRESS #28 Et
TRAP #30 At
LOT #34 Ox; may be merged with #32 Ah or #33 Awe or both
STRUT #36 Utter
FOOT #39 Foot; may be merged with #36 Utter or #40 Ooze
BATH Either #30 At or #32 Ah, depending on dialect
CLOTH Either #34 Ox or #33 Awe, depending on dialect [*]
NURSE #36 Utter followed by #25 Roe
FLEECE #27 Eat
FACE #29 Eight
PALM #32 Ah; may be merged with #33 Awe or #34 Ox or both
THOUGHT #33 Awe; may be merged with #32 Ah or #34 Ox or both
GOAT #38 Owe
GOOSE #40 Ooze; may be merged with #39 Foot
PRICE #31 I; may be merged with #32 Ah
CHOICE #35 Oy
MOUTH #37 Out
NEAR #27 Eat followed by #25 Roe
SQUARE #29 Eight or #28 Et, depending on dialect, followed by #25 Roe
START #32 Ah [*] followed by #25 Roe
NORTH #34 On [*] or #38 Owe, depending on dialect, followed by #25 Roe
FORCE #38 Owe or #34 On [*], depending on dialect, followed by #25 Roe
CURE #40 Ooze or #33 Awe [*], depending on dialect, followed by #25 Roe
HAPPY Read says #26 It, although #27 Eat is used by most people now
LETTER #36 Utter followed by #25 Roe
COMMA #36 Utter

[*] May involve further mergers.

It's only rough because there are other mergers in various dialects
that aren't represented here: psalm/sum, bud/bird, pin/pen, mit/meet,
met/mat, meet/mate, bit/bet, cot/coat, rod/ride, pride/proud, line/loin,
merry/Mary/merry, hurry/furry, furry/ferry, cheer/chair, fur/fair,
stir/steer, tower/tire, tower/tar, tire/tar, cure/fir, card/cord. Yes,
somewhere there is a group of people who pronounce each pair of words
identically (and not just those words, many other pairs too).

--
John Cowan <cowan@...> http://www.ccil.org/~cowan
Today an interactive brochure website, tomorrow a global content
management system that leverages collective synergy to drive "outside of

with a quality-driven approach that focuses on empowering key players
to drive-up their core competencies and increase expectations with an
all-around initiative to drive up the bottom-line. --Alex Papadimoulis

Here's a rough mapping from the 27 Wells lexical sets
(reminder: you can see sample words at
http://www.ic.arizona.edu/~anth383/lexicalsets.html )
to QS vowel letters and combinations:

KIT         #26 It
DRESS       #28 Et
TRAP        #30 At
LOT         #34 Ox; may be merged with #32 Ah or #33 Awe or both
STRUT       #36 Utter
FOOT        #39 Foot; may be merged with #36 Utter or #40 Ooze
BATH        Either #30 At or #32 Ah, depending on dialect
CLOTH       Either #34 Ox or #33 Awe, depending on dialect [*]
NURSE       #36 Utter followed by #25 Roe
FLEECE      #27 Eat
FACE        #29 Eight
PALM        #32 Ah; may be merged with #33 Awe or #34 Ox or both
THOUGHT     #33 Awe; may be merged with #32 Ah or #34 Ox or both
GOAT        #38 Owe
GOOSE       #40 Ooze; may be merged with #39 Foot
PRICE       #31 I; may be merged with #32 Ah
CHOICE      #35 Oy
MOUTH       #37 Out
NEAR        #27 Eat followed by #25 Roe
SQUARE      #29 Eight or #28 Et, depending on dialect, followed by #25 Roe
START       #32 Ah [*] followed by #25 Roe
NORTH       #34 On [*] or #38 Owe, depending on dialect, followed by #25 Roe
FORCE       #38 Owe or #34 On [*], depending on dialect, followed by #25 Roe
CURE        #40 Ooze or #33 Awe [*], depending on dialect, followed by #25 Roe
HAPPY       Read says #26 It, although #27 Eat is used by most people now
LETTER      #36 Utter followed by #25 Roe
COMMA       #36 Utter

[*] May involve further mergers.

It's only rough because there are other mergers in various dialects
that aren't represented here:  psalm/sum, bud/bird, pin/pen, mit/meet,
met/mat, meet/mate, bit/bet, cot/coat, rod/ride, pride/proud, line/loin,
merry/Mary/merry, hurry/furry, furry/ferry, cheer/chair, fur/fair,
stir/steer, tower/tire, tower/tar, tire/tar, cure/fir, card/cord.  Yes,
somewhere there is a group of people who pronounce each pair of words
identically (and not just those words, many other pairs too).

--
